Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a hybrid sputtering/evaporation thin film deposition system
Award.AbstractNarration:
Part 1: This award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program supports research and training at California State University San Bernardino (CSUSB) through the acquisition of a thin film sputter deposition system. The proposed deposition system allows the principal investigator to grow high-quality ferroic oxide thin films and multilayers. By controlling the film thickness and composition, specific material properties or combinations of properties can be fine-tuned. This system will be utilized alongside the existing capabilities of the NSF-CREST funded CSUSB Center for Advanced Functional Materials, which will allow for the creation and characterization of novel hybrid organic/oxide systems as well as broaden student research participation and training at a large Hispanic- and minority-serving institution. The development of thin films for research aims and applications has led to important discoveries that have advanced the understanding of the interesting science at play in these films as well as allowed an accelerated development of technological materials. Ferroic materials, including ferroelectric and magnetic and multiferroics, have "led the charge" in many areas of research and development and will continue to do so in the future. As the need to understand and engineer ferroic thin film systems that can operate faster, more efficiently, or display novel functional properties grows, acquiring high-quality thin films will play a vital role in research programs centered around functional material studies.

Part 2: This award supports the acquisition of a thin film sputter deposition system for scientific research and research training at California State University San Bernardino (CSUSB). This system will be used to deposit thin films and multilayered samples as a part of several research both within CSUSB and with domestic and international collaborators. It will combine off-axis rf-magneton sputtering and existing thermal evaporation capabilities in order to engineer a wide variety of single crystal and polycrystalline samples. The use of two techniques will allow research on novel systems combining often dissimilar materials, such as oxide and organic ferroelectrics, as well as allow for in-situ deposition of bottom electrodes, which can help avoid problems of interfacial contamination or electrically dead layers. This instrument supports research efforts by current faculty members, visiting graduate students, and undergraduate researchers and will enhance CSUSB's NSF-CREST funded Center for Advanced Functional Materials (CAFM). Current research focus includes: 1) Engineering novel ferroelectric and magnetic properties into single crystal oxide thin films using a variety of control parameters accessible though film growth including epitaxial strain and multilayer growth 2) Developing organic ferroelectric thin films 3) The study of functional hybrid organic/oxide systems. This award will increase the research infrastructure at CSUSB, particularly by furthering access to equipment for the deposition of a wide variety of thin films. CSUSB is an undergraduate-focused university and a qualifying Hispanic- and Minority-Serving institution, allowing the acquisition of this instrument to broaden participation of students from these demographics in state-of-the-art research. Community college partnerships will broaden the local reach of the instrumentation and further develop the STEM pipeline in the local area. Through the CREST program, the feasibility of a Materials Science Masters program is being investigated and a hybrid deposition system would serve as a major facility for research projects and training associated with such a program. Additionally, the ability to provide high-quality thin film samples will support the development of strong domestic and international collaborations focusing on the characterization of new thin film based systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI grant was to fund the acquisition and commissioning of an off-axis rf sputter deposition that will be used to grow ferroic oxide thin films. The materials of interest here have applications across a wide range of technologies, including memory and sensor devices. This deposition system will enhance CSUSB's NSF-CREST funded Center for Advanced Functional Materials by expanding the center's thin films capabilities and allowing us to incorporate oxide materials into current research that mainly focused on organic ferroelectrics. This system will also lead to additional opportunities for students at CSUSB, a Minority- and Hispanic-Serving Institute (MSI/HSI), to participate in state-of-the-art research and develop experimental and instrumentation skills beneficial for participation in the STEM workforce.

 During the first year of this grant, a custom-built deposition system was designed by and purchased from AJA International, a US company that is a leader in sputter, evaporation, and ion-milling systems. The purchase was finalized in March 2018 and the system was delivered to CSUSB in October 2018. During the second year of the grant, the facilities to install the deposition system were finalized and the system was fully installed and comissioned with the help of an on-site technician from AJA International. During commissioning, the PIs, the College of Natural Science equipment technician, and CSUSB students were trained on system operation. Once users were fully trained, they participated in projects, carried out by students, to callibrate growth conditions to optimize the film quality of well-known ferroic systems with which the PI has previously worked, such as LaSrMnO3, SrRuO3, or PbTiO3. This will allow us to master operation of the new system before proceeding on to more novel materials where there will be more un-knowns in terms of deposition parameters. 

Overall, 9 undergraduate students were involved in research related to the sputtering chamber and film deposition system.The major projects they worked on include: building a custom ferroelectric test system for future use with film samples,determining the process to use prepare atomically flat substrates using hydrothermal etching and high temperature annealing, set up of an ellipsometer that will be used to characterize films in situ during growth, and deposition of SrRuO3 and La1-xSrxMnO3 films. All students have received mentoring on not only how scientific research is carried out in a professional setting, but also inthe "softer" skills transferrable to a wide variety of career paths. This includes dissemination practices, such as creating conference abstracts and presentations, and laboratory documentation and safety practices. As an MSI/HSI, CSUSB is well positioned to help increase the diversity of who participates in the materials (and broaderSTEM) workforce. Of the 9 total students who have been involved over the life of the grant, 6 have been Hispanic and 6 have been first-generation college students. All students have had opportunities to present their work both in the local CSUSB area at at regional undergraduate research conferences. 

The majority of materials research at CSUSB, mainly funded by the NSF CREST program, occurs under the umbrella of the Center for Advanced Functional Materials (CAFM). Recently research has been expanded into the area thin films. So farwork has focused on organic ferroelectric thin films. The newly acquired deposition system supports the CAFM but goes along way in expanding the research focus beyond organic materials by allowing the deposition of functional oxides. This will allow the CAFM to work with materials with relatively well-characterized structural behavior that can lead to the study of novel funcitonal properties, such as magnetism or multiferroicity, which are somewhat tangential to the original scope of the CAFM,which focused on organic ferroelectric and piezoelectric materials.The acquired sputtering system will play a large role in the expansion of the CAFM over the next five years, which will befacilitied by the awarded of a second round of CREST funding (Award #1914777), set to begin in early 2020. While thin films are a small component of the original round of CREST funding, they are one of the three major research thrusts ofthe next five years of the center. This is due in no small part to the acquisition of the oxide sputtering system, which will allow us not only to expand to thin films, but also to work on systems beyond organic ferroelectrics. Additionally, once films of the initial materials are gauged to be high-quality, we will be able to send them to collaborators to be used in various research projects.
